title: Elizabeth Warren Is Set to Play a Big Campaign Role
authors: Laura Meckler, Kristina Peterson, Laura.Meckler Wsj.Com, Kristina.Peterson Wsj.Com
content:
WASHINGTON—Hillary Clinton huddled for an hour Friday with Sen. Elizabeth Warren in what many Democrats see as an important step in unifying the party after its bruising presidential primary .
The Massachusetts senator is set to play a key role , both as a determined and pointed critic of Republican Donald Trump and as someone whom liberal supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders inherently trust . Friday ’ s meeting also fueled chatter—highly speculative—that Mrs. Clinton would pick her as a running mate .
Before Mr. Sanders launched his long shot run for president , the party ’ s liberals had urged Ms. Warren to run . She declined , and she also wouldn ’ t endorse either candidate in the long primary , making her one of the most prominent Democrats to remain neutral .
“ The perfect person to be helpful is Elizabeth Warren , because she didn ’ t take a stand for either one , ” Sen. Barbara Boxer ( D. , Calif. ) volunteered when asked about unification . “ I think that may be perfect for her . ”
In recent weeks , Ms. Warren has been ramping up her role in the campaign , sharply attacking Mr. Trump without mentioning either Democrat , and then on Thursday endorsing Mrs. Clinton .
Mr. Sanders says he will continue to campaign through the last primary , on Tuesday in Washington , D.C. , but he hasn ’ t indicated what he will do after that . Mrs. Clinton has more than enough delegates to claim the nomination and declared victory this past week . On Thursday , Ms. Warren declared flatly , “ Hillary Clinton won . And she won because she ’ s a fighter , she ’ s out there , she ’ s tough . ”
Mrs. Clinton returned the affection . Speaking before the Planned Parenthood Action Fund on Friday , she mentioned the Warren endorsement in the same breath as those from President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden . “ So it ’ s been a big week , ” she said .
In their meeting Friday at Mrs. Clinton ’ s Washington home , she and Ms. Warren discussed working together over the coming campaign to advance their agendas and block Mr. Trump , officials said . Mrs. Clinton also thanked her for her endorsement , a Clinton aide said .
On Capitol Hill , lawmakers view Ms. Warren as an ascending leader , whose liberal followers give her an influence well beyond her short Senate tenure . Lawmakers speak with reverence of her Facebook following ( nearly 2.2 million likes ) and the fact that Mr. Trump regularly responds to her attacks . She is widely expected to continue as a strong voice for the populist wing of the party no matter who wins the presidential election .
Following the 2014 midterm elections , Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid named Ms. Warren a top adviser to Senate Democrats ’ policy and communications arm .
Before being elected to the Senate in 2012 , Ms. Warren had already made her mark . An expert on bankruptcy and a law professor at Harvard University , she served as chairman of the congressionally appointed watchdog panel of the 2008 Troubled Asset Relief Program and then set up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau , which she pushed Congress to create .
“ Nobody has the integrity when it comes to Wall Street and reining in the excesses of our capitalist society…like Elizabeth Warren , ” Rep. Luis Gutierrez ( D. , Ill. ) said Friday . He said Mr. Sanders won credibility through his well-funded campaign but that Ms. Warren “ had it from the very , very beginning . ”
Democrats view Ms. Warren as one of the party ’ s best communicators—someone who can crisply dismantle GOP arguments , and in particular , those of Mr. Trump .
Republicans have said Ms. Warren is hypocritical for railing against Wall Street , then endorsing Mrs. Clinton , who has given highly paid speeches to big financial institutions .
At times , Ms. Warren ’ s sharp political skills have complicated the life of Democratic leaders . In December 2014 , she opposed a provision in a $ 1.1 trillion spending bill that would have scaled back language in the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial-regulation law , and nearly derailed the legislation .
Some liberal lawmakers said they would prefer Ms. Warren as a running mate over a more centrist Democrat such as Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia , who has longed been buzzed about as a possible Clinton running mate .
“ Sen . Kaine ’ s a wonderful public servant , but if you really want to electrify the base , you ’ ve got to get somebody who ’ s been speaking to the base and is going to turn the base out , ” Rep. Keith Ellison ( D. , Minn. ) , co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus , said Friday . “ She ’ s already been bringing it Donald Trump ’ s way in electrifying fashion . ”

The Massachusetts senator is set to play a key role, both as a determined and pointed critic of Republican Donald Trump and as someone whom liberal supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders inherently trust. Friday’s meeting also fueled chatter—highly speculative—that Mrs. Clinton would pick her as a running mate.

Before Mr. Sanders launched his long shot run for president, the party’s liberals had urged Ms. Warren to run. She declined, and she also wouldn’t endorse either candidate in the long primary, making her one of the most prominent Democrats to remain neutral.

“The perfect person to be helpful is Elizabeth Warren, because she didn’t take a stand for either one,” Sen. Barbara Boxer (D., Calif.) volunteered when asked about unification. “I think that may be perfect for her.”

In recent weeks, Ms. Warren has been ramping up her role in the campaign, sharply attacking Mr. Trump without mentioning either Democrat, and then on Thursday endorsing Mrs. Clinton.

Mr. Sanders says he will continue to campaign through the last primary, on Tuesday in Washington, D.C., but he hasn’t indicated what he will do after that. Mrs. Clinton has more than enough delegates to claim the nomination and declared victory this past week. On Thursday, Ms. Warren declared flatly, “Hillary Clinton won. And she won because she’s a fighter, she’s out there, she’s tough.”

Mrs. Clinton returned the affection. Speaking before the Planned Parenthood Action Fund on Friday, she mentioned the Warren endorsement in the same breath as those from President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden. “So it’s been a big week,” she said.

In a speech Thursday night, Sen. Elizabeth Warren strongly criticized Donald Trump for his remarks that Judge Gonzalo Curiel, who is overseeing lawsuits against Trump University, is biased because of being of Mexican heritage. Photo: AP

In their meeting Friday at Mrs. Clinton’s Washington home, she and Ms. Warren discussed working together over the coming campaign to advance their agendas and block Mr. Trump, officials said. Mrs. Clinton also thanked her for her endorsement, a Clinton aide said.

On Capitol Hill, lawmakers view Ms. Warren as an ascending leader, whose liberal followers give her an influence well beyond her short Senate tenure. Lawmakers speak with reverence of her Facebook following (nearly 2.2 million likes) and the fact that Mr. Trump regularly responds to her attacks. She is widely expected to continue as a strong voice for the populist wing of the party no matter who wins the presidential election.

Following the 2014 midterm elections, Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid named Ms. Warren a top adviser to Senate Democrats’ policy and communications arm.

Before being elected to the Senate in 2012, Ms. Warren had already made her mark. An expert on bankruptcy and a law professor at Harvard University, she served as chairman of the congressionally appointed watchdog panel of the 2008 Troubled Asset Relief Program and then set up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which she pushed Congress to create.

“Nobody has the integrity when it comes to Wall Street and reining in the excesses of our capitalist society…like Elizabeth Warren,” Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D., Ill.) said Friday. He said Mr. Sanders won credibility through his well-funded campaign but that Ms. Warren “had it from the very, very beginning.”

Democrats view Ms. Warren as one of the party’s best communicators—someone who can crisply dismantle GOP arguments, and in particular, those of Mr. Trump.

Republicans have said Ms. Warren is hypocritical for railing against Wall Street, then endorsing Mrs. Clinton, who has given highly paid speeches to big financial institutions.

At times, Ms. Warren’s sharp political skills have complicated the life of Democratic leaders. In December 2014, she opposed a provision in a $1.1 trillion spending bill that would have scaled back language in the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial-regulation law, and nearly derailed the legislation.

Some liberal lawmakers said they would prefer Ms. Warren as a running mate over a more centrist Democrat such as Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia, who has longed been buzzed about as a possible Clinton running mate.

“Sen. Kaine’s a wonderful public servant, but if you really want to electrify the base, you’ve got to get somebody who’s been speaking to the base and is going to turn the base out,” Rep. Keith Ellison (D., Minn.), co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, said Friday. “She’s already been bringing it Donald Trump’s way in electrifying fashion.”

—Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.
